case_name: State of Bihar and the Additional Collector of Darbhanga v. the respondent

facts.text: The case is an appeal numbered Civil Appeal No. 425 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 425 of 1957.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1956 of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 53 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1956, of the Patna High Court in Misc. Judicial Case No. 53 of 1955.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on May 3, 1961 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. May 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-

facts.text: Plots No. 383 and 1033 are tanks in village Lakshmipur alias Tarauni in the District of Darbhanga.

anchor.surface_text: Plots NOW. 383 and 1033 are tanks in village Lakshmipur alias Tarauni in the District of Darbhanga.

facts.text: The respondent took settlement of plots 383 and 1033 in the year 1943 from the landlords of Raghopur Estate.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claims to have taken settlement of the said plots in the year 1943 from the landlords of Raghopur Estate of which the said plots formed a part.

facts.text: The said plots formed a part of Raghopur Estate.

anchor.surface_text: of Raghopur Estate of which the said plots formed a part.

facts.text: After the coming into force of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950, the Raghopur Estate vested in the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: After the coming into force of the Act, the said Estate vested in the State of Bihar.

facts.text: Sheonandan Jha and some other villagers of Lakshmipur filed a petition before the Collector alleging the settlement was not true and was nominally effected only after January 1, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, one Sheonandan Jha and some other villagers of Lakshmipur filed a petition before the Collector alleging that the alleged settlement was number true, and that in fact the settlement was numberinally effected only after January 1, 1946.

facts.text: The Additional Collector, Darbhanga held that the settlement was actually made after January 1, 1946 and was a paper transaction.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Collector, Darbhanga, in exercise of the powers companyferred on him under s. 4 h  of the Act, held that the said settlement was actually made after January 1, 1946, and that it was only a paper transaction

facts.text: The Additional Collector annulled the settlement by order dated January 18, 1955 and directed the respondent to give up possession by January 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: having annulled the said settlement, the Additional Collector, by his order dated January 18, 1955, called upon the respondent to give up possession of the said plots by January 30, 1955.

facts.text: The respondent filed a petition under Article 226 in Patna High Court seeking writ to cancel Additional Collector's order dated January 18, 1955 and restrain interference with possession.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the said order, the respondent filed a petition in the High Court of Judicature at Patna under Art. 226 of the Constitution for a rule in the nature of a writ of mandamus or any other appropriate writ cancelling the order of the Additional Collector dated January 18, 1955, and res-

facts.text: Patna High Court division bench held by order dated February 21, 1956 that Additional Collector had no jurisdiction to decide whether settlement prima facie before January 1, 1946 was actually after.

anchor.surface_text: That petition came to be decided by a division bench of the High Court and the learned Judges by their order dated February 21, 1956, held that the Additional Collector had numberjurisdiction to entertain and decide the question whether the settlement, which was prima facie shown to have been made before January 1, 1946, was actually made after that date.

facts.text: Patna High Court set aside the order of the Additional Collector.

anchor.surface_text: On the basis of that finding, the order of the Additional Collector was set aside.

facts.text: State of Bihar and Additional Collector of Darbhanga preferred the present appeal against the High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bihar and the Additional Collector of Darbhanga have preferred the present appeal against the said order.

facts.text: The appeal was by certificate.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate raises the question

facts.text: Learned counsel for the respondent conceded the retroactivity of the amendment.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent, while conceding the retroactivity of the amendment, relies upon the second proviso added by the amendment to s. 4 h

facts.text: There was no confirmation of the Collector's order by the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: relies upon the second proviso added by the amendment to s. 4 h  and contends that under the said proviso the order of the Collector cannot take effect number possession taken thereunder, unless the said order has been confirmed by the State Government and that in the instant case there has number been any such confirmation.

facts.text: In the affidavit in High Court, there is no specific allegation that no inquiry was made or no sanction obtained.

anchor.surface_text: In the affidavit filed in support of the petition in the High Court there is no specific allegation that no such inquiry has been made or that no such sanction has been obtained.

facts.text: Counsel for the appellant did not raise the issue of inquiry or sanction before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Nor did the counsel for the appellant raise the said question in the arguments before the High Court.

facts.text: The Supreme Court set aside the order of the High Court and allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we set aside the order of the High Court and allow the appeal.

facts.text: The Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 is Act 30 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: construction of s. 4 h  of the Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950  Act 30 of 1950   hereinafter referred to as the Act ,

facts.text: The Amending Act is Bihar Land Reforms Amendment Act, 1959 (Bihar Act 16 of 1959).

anchor.surface_text: as amended by the Bihar Land Reforms  Amendment  Act, 1959  Bihar Act 16 of 1959   hereinafter called the Amending Act .

facts.text: K. P. Sinha and D. P. Singh appeared for the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: K. P. Sinha and D. P. Singh, for the appellants.

facts.text: K. Jha and R. C. Prasad appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: K. Jha and R. C. Prasad, for the respondent.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that section 4(h) of the Act is protected by Article 31A of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: under the amended section the order made by the Collector shall neither take effect nor can he take possession before his order is confirmed. arguments.claim: The Additional Collector had no jurisdiction to entertain and decide the question whether the settlement, which was prima facie shown to have been made before January 1, 1946, was actually made after that date.

anchor.surface_text: held that the Additional Collector had nojurisdiction to entertain and decide the question whether the settlement, which was prima facie shown to have been made before January 1, 1946, was actually made after that date.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: een amended with retrospective effect, that under the amended section the Collector has power to decide whether a transfer is made before 1946 or ther

arguments.court_reasoning: Amendment to s.4(h) is retrospective, expressly conferring power on Collector to inquire into transfers prima facie before or after Jan 1, 1946.

arguments.claim: s. 4(h) of the Act has been amended with retrospective effect, under the amended section the Collector has power to decide whether a transfer is made before 1946 or thereafter, and therefore the order of the High Court can no longer be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the State contends that s. 4 h of the Act has been amended with retrospective effect, that under the amended section the Collector has power to decide whether a transfer is made before 1946 or thereafter, and that, therefore, the order of the High Court can no longer be sustained.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: l have power to make inquiries in respect of any transfer including the settlement if he is satisfied that such transfer was made at any time after th

arguments.court_reasoning: Amendments in cls. (iv)(a) and (b) use 'deemed always to have been', making them retrospective.

arguments.claim: Under the second proviso added by the amendment to s. 4(h), the order of the Collector cannot take effect nor possession taken thereunder unless confirmed by the State Government, and there has been no such confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent, while conceding the retroactivity of the amendment, relies upon the second proviso added by the amendment to s. 4 h and contends that under the said proviso the order of the Collector cannot take effect nor possession taken thereunder, unless the said order has been confirmed by the State Government and that in the instant case there has no been any such confirmation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: l have power to make inquiries in respect of any transfer including the settlement if he is satisfied that such transfer was made at any time after th

arguments.court_reasoning: Second proviso prospective as no deeming language unlike cls. (iv)(a)(b); different phraseology; harmonious construction avoids conflict and redundancy.

arguments.claim: s. 4(h) infringes fundamental rights under Arts. 14, 19 and 31 and is not saved by Art. 31A.

anchor.surface_text: Further he questions the constitutional validity of the said section on the ground that it infringes the fundamental right of the respondent under Arts. 14, 19 and 31 of the Constitution and is no saved by Art. 31A thereof.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: id section on the ground that it infringes the fundamental right of the respondent under Arts. 14, 19 and 31 of the Constitution and is number saved b

arguments.court_reasoning: s.4(h) integral ancillary provision to prevent fraud and effectuate vesting; protected by Art.31A; precedent_following Thakur Raghubir Singh v. State of Ajmer.

arguments.claim: s. 4(h) is protected by Art. 31A as it is an integral part of the Act designed to extinguish/modify rights in estate and offset anticipatory fraud.

anchor.surface_text: This argument in effect disannexes s. 4 h of the Act from the setting in which it appears and seeks to test its validity independently of its interaction on the other provisions of the Act. Section 4 h is an integral part of the Act, and taken out of the Act it can only operate in vacuum.

arguments.claim: The Collector did not make inquiry in strict compliance with s.4(h) provisions and did not obtain previous sanction of State Government.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, it is argued by learned counsel for the respondent that the High Court, presumably in view of its acceptance of the respondents preliminary point, did not consider the question whether the inquiry had been made by the Collector in strict compliance with the provisions of the section, and whether the previous sanction of the State Government was obtained before he made the said order.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ribute to the Legislature redundancy but would also enable a party to seek for restoration of the land taken possession of by the Collector on the bas

arguments.court_reasoning: No specific allegation in High Court affidavit; not raised in High Court arguments; cannot be raised first time in SC.

holdings.text: s. 4(h) of the Act is likewise protected by Art. 31A of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The same reasoning applies to s. 4 h  of the Act, and for the same reasons we hold that s. 4 h  of the Act is likewise protected by Art. 31A of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 4(h) is an integral ancillary provision to prevent anticipatory fraud by landlords, effectuating vesting of estates; follows reasoning in Thakur Raghubir Singh v. State of Ajmer upholding similar s.8.

holdings.text: Under the amended s.4(h), the Collector has power to inquire into and annul transfers made at any time after January 1, 1946, with retrospective effect as per cls.(iv)(a) and (b) of s.3 Amending Act.

anchor.surface_text: The different phraseology used in cls.  a  and  b  of subs.  iv  of s. 3 of the Amending Act in the matter of omissions supports it. While in cl.  a  the omission ,hall be deemed always to have been omitted,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendments use 'deemed always to have been' language making cls.(iv)(a),(b) retrospective, conferring power retrospectively unlike original ambiguity.

holdings.text: The second proviso to s.4(h) added by Amending Act is prospective only, not retrospective; previous sanction suffices for pre-amendment orders.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that in respect of an order already made by the Collector before the Amending Act, the previous sanction obtained would suffice, and in respect of an order made after the Amending Act, a subsequent confirmation by the State Government is required.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No deeming language in cl.(v) unlike cls.(iv)(a),(b); different phraseology; harmonious construction avoids conflict, redundancy, incongruity.

holdings.text: Respondent cannot raise question of Collector's compliance with inquiry and previous sanction provisions for first time in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we do number think that this Court is justified in allowing the respondent to raise the said question for the first time before us. We, therefore, reject this plea.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No specific allegation in High Court affidavit; issue not raised or argued before High Court.

precedents.case_name: Thakur Raghubir Singh v. State of Ajmer
precedents.cited_proposition: A provision empowering the Collector to cancel transfers or leases made in anticipation of land reform legislation is ancillary to the main objectives of the Act and protected under Article 31A of the Constitution
precedents.cited_holding: The provision is number an independent provision it is merely ancillary in character enacted for carrying out the objects of the Act more effectively Such cancellation would sub-serve the purposes of the Act, and the provision for it therefore be an integral part of the Act, though ancillary to its main object, and would thus be protected under Art. 31A 1 a of the Constitution.
